poem:
**Dispatches**

A question mark hangs  
like a shadow, lingers—  
fragile doubt in ink.  
What weight does it  
carry, this tiny curl,  
when wrapped in  
the gravity of truth  
seeking eyes?  
Newsprint crumbles,  
quiet agitator,  
yet remains unmet  
by the syllables  
of certainty, perhaps—a  
comma turned to sigh.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Trump: Moscow’s Man in the White House? review – a lazy, galling failure of a documentary It’s never a particularly encouraging sign when the title of a documentary ends with a question mark. It might just be a tiny scrap of punctuation, and yet it can single-handedly undermine an entire thesis. Take the latest episode of Dispatches. A film called Trump: Moscow’s Man in the White House would hit like a juggernaut. That film would". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
